column2: The futuristic tech in this movie is so cool. The gesture-based computers are iconic.
The reveal that Lamar Burgess, the founder of Precrime, is the real villain who framed Anderton is a huge twist.
The action sequences are top-notch. The jetpack chase is amazing.
Anderton realizing that Precrime is flawed because of the 'minority reports' and human choice... that's the whole movie.
The concept of Precrime is so fascinating and terrifying. It raises so many ethical questions.
The ending, with the Precrime program being dismantled and the pre-cogs freed, is a victory for free will.
The visual style of this movie is so unique. That desaturated, high-contrast look is perfect.
The moment Anderton chooses not to kill Crow, proving the future isn't set, is the turning point.
Tom Cruise is great in this. It's one of his best action-sci-fi roles.
The scene with the robotic spiders scanning everyone's eyes is pure nightmare fuel.
The movie is a brilliant neo-noir thriller disguised as a sci-fi blockbuster.
The fact that Burgess created a murder 'echo' to get away with it is a genius and diabolical plan.
The world-building is incredible. It feels so detailed and lived-in.
The pre-cogs living in their milk bath is such a strange and haunting image.
The film is a smart and thrilling ride from start to finish.
The final confrontation between Anderton and Burgess, with the 'you have a choice' dilemma, is a perfect climax.
The 'spill and roll' balls to track perps are a cool gadget.
The moment Anderton gets new eyes to avoid detection is so gnarly.
This is one of Spielberg's most underrated movies. It's a masterpiece.
Agatha being the key to the whole mystery, and the most powerful pre-cog, is a great reveal.
The idea of personalized ads that talk to you is both cool and terrifyingly close to reality.
The ending is a powerful statement about the danger of sacrificing freedom for security.
The pacing is relentless. It just doesn't let up.
The reveal of what happened to Anderton's son is heartbreaking and drives his whole character.
The sick stick is a great non-lethal weapon concept.
The pre-cogs being able to live a normal life at the end is a hopeful conclusion.
The film is a great adaptation of the Philip K. Dick story.
The moment when the pre-cogs predict Anderton will commit a murder is when the movie kicks into high gear.
The supporting cast is fantastic, especially Max von Sydow as Burgess.
The final choice Burgess makes, to kill himself rather than let Precrime be discredited, is a tragic end.
The film is a complex and thought-provoking thriller.
The way Anderton has to use his knowledge of the system to beat the system is so compelling.
The visual of the pre-cogs' visions is so unique and memorable.
The ending, with Anderton reuniting with his wife and expecting a new child, brings his story full circle.
The movie is a perfect blend of high-concept sci-fi and classic detective story.
The reveal of the 'minority report' completely changes our understanding of how Precrime works.
The ethical dilemma of punishing people for crimes they haven't committed yet is the core of the film.
The way Burgess kills himself to validate Precrime is a dark and twisted act of pride.
The car factory sequence is an amazing action set piece.
The film is a cautionary tale about the dangers of a surveillance state.
The scene where Anderton is hiding in the ice bath is so tense.
The ending is a win for humanity over a flawed system.
The technology feels so futuristic yet believable.
The way the film explores themes of fate vs. free will is brilliant.
The visual of the wooden balls with the victims' and perpetrators' names is iconic.
The final scene of the pre-cogs reading in peace is a beautiful image of freedom.
The script is so tight and clever. Every detail matters.
The moment Anderton realizes his own system is hunting him is a great reversal.
The movie is a stylish and intelligent sci-fi masterpiece.
The revelation about Anne Lively's murder being covered up by Burgess is the key to unraveling everything.
The way the film builds its world through small details is amazing.
The ending is a powerful argument for the importance of human imperfection and choice.
The performances are all top-notch.
Burgess's suicide is the ultimate proof that the future can be changed, which ironically dismantles his life's work.
The movie is a thrilling and thought-provoking ride.
The way Anderton uses Agatha's pre-cog abilities to navigate is so cool.
The film's vision of the future is both exciting and terrifying.
The ending is a satisfying conclusion to a complex and thrilling story.
The editing is so sharp and kinetic.
The twist that Burgess is the villain is so well-hidden in plain sight.
The movie is a classic of the sci-fi genre.
The fact that Anderton had to become a fugitive to prove the system's flaws is great irony.
The look of the film is so distinct and memorable.
The final showdown is a battle of wits and wills, not just fists.
A truly brilliant and entertaining film.
The 'minority report' concept is a genius plot device.
The movie is a deep dive into some heavy philosophical questions.
The ending, where justice is finally served and the innocent are freed, is so rewarding.
The tech in this film influenced a lot of real-world design.
The way the mystery unfolds is masterfully done.
The film is a perfect example of how to do a smart, adult sci-fi movie.
The ending is a powerful defense of free will over predestination.
The action is visceral and creative.
The reveal that Burgess set the whole thing up to protect his legacy is a classic noir motive.
The movie is a visual and intellectual feast.
The final scene of Anderton finding peace is a well-earned happy ending.
The world feels so fully realized and believable.
The way the film uses the pre-cogs' visions as a storytelling tool is so innovative.
A modern classic that's still relevant today.
The ending proves that even a perfect system can be corrupted by human flaws.
The pacing is perfect. It never lets you get comfortable.
The moment Anderton realizes he can change his future is the thematic core of the film.
The movie is a smart, stylish, and action-packed thriller.
The final confrontation is a perfect chess match between two brilliant minds.
The film is a timeless exploration of justice and morality.
The way Burgess is trapped by his own system at the end is perfect poetic justice.
The visual effects still hold up incredibly well.
The final scene of the pre-cogs living a quiet life is a beautiful and peaceful conclusion.
The movie is a masterpiece of the genre.
The twist about the two different types of murders ('red ball' and 'brown ball') is a clever detail.
The film is a thrilling cat-and-mouse game from start to finish.
The ending is a powerful statement about the value of human choice and error.
The world of 2054 feels both futuristic and grounded.
The way the film combines action, mystery, and philosophy is seamless.
A classic Spielberg film that gets better with every watch.
The final scene is a perfect resolution, with Anderton finding closure and the pre-cogs finding freedom.
